Trial_Design.evidence: This was a randomised single-blind study involving 90 surgical patients requiring endotracheal intubation.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised into 3 groups: A (control), B (intra-cuff magnesium sulphate) and C (intravenous magnesium sulphate).

Objective.evidence: This study sought to compare the effects of intravenous and intra-cuff magnesium sulphate on the incidence and severity of PEST, cough and hoarseness of voice.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The occurrence of PEST, cough and hoarseness of voice were recorded at 0, 4, 8, 12 and 24 h after surgery.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of PEST on swallowing in the intra-cuff magnesium sulphate group compared to the intravenous magnesium sulphate group at 4, 8, and 12 h post-operatively were 51.7% vs 12.5%, 51.7% vs 18.8% and 51.7% vs 21.9% respectively.
